question_answer_pairs.answer: The date of the document is 23 May 2013.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the sender of the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The sender of the document is RAJIV MEHTA, Director General of Narcotics Control Bureau, West Block-1, Wing-6, R.K. Puram, New Delhi.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the recipient of the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The recipient of the document is Dear Shri Mohanty.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the subject of the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The subject of the document is Observance of 26th June 2013 as 'International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking'.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose of the document is to provide necessary directions regarding the observance of the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking on 26th June 2013.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: When was the UN General Assembly resolution on the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking passed?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The UN General Assembly resolution on the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking was passed in December 1987.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the frequency of the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking is observed every year.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of observing the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose of observing the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking is to raise public awareness regarding the menace of drugs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the various programs and activities suggested to be organized on 26th June 2013?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The various programs and activities suggested to be organized on 26th June 2013 include awareness programs in schools and colleges, public meetings in areas and among target groups vulnerable to drug abuse, anti-drug marches/runs/rallies, seminars on drug abuse in training institutions/voluntary organizations, workshops to evolve new coordinated strategies for supply reduction and demand reduction by the various enforcement agencies/NGOs, exhibitions on drug abuse in different cities and towns, and regional language programs to be discussed/broadcast by Doordarshan/All India Radio and other electronic channels.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What type of wide publicity is suggested to be given?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Wide publicity is suggested to be given by way of displaying and distribution of banners, posters, hoardings, and audio-visual shows in cinemas, etc.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of observing the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose is to raise public awareness regarding the menace of drugs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the resolution passed by the UN General Assembly regarding the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The UN General Assembly passed a resolution in December 1987 declaring 26th June as the \"International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking\".\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How often is the International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking observed?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The International Day against Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking is observed every year.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the various activities suggested to be organized on 26th June 2013?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The various activities suggested include awareness programs in schools and colleges, public meetings, anti-drug marches/runs/rallies, seminars, workshops, exhibitions, and regional language programs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the wide publicity suggested?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The wide publicity is suggested to be given by way of displaying and distribution of banners, posters, hoardings, and audio-visual shows in cinemas, etc. to raise public awareness.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the main purpose of the circular document mentioned in the text?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The main purpose of the circular document is to provide instructions and guidelines for the implementation of the Rastriya Swasthya Bima Yojana (RSBY) scheme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the RSBY scheme mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The RSBY scheme is a health insurance scheme for the poor and underprivileged sections of society.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: According to the document, what are the key features of the RSBY scheme?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The key features of the RSBY scheme mentioned in the document include providing health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 30,000 per family per year, no age limit for the beneficiaries, and the scheme being cashless and paperless.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the role of the district administration in the implementation of the RSBY scheme as per the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The district administration is responsible for the implementation and monitoring of the RSBY scheme at the district level.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How are the beneficiaries of the RSBY scheme identified according to the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The beneficiaries of the RSBY scheme are identified based on the BPL (Below Poverty Line) list prepared by the state government.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the process of enrollment of the beneficiaries into the RSBY scheme as per the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The beneficiaries are enrolled into the RSBY scheme through a smart card that is issued to them, which contains their personal and family details.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who are the key stakeholders involved in the implementation of the RSBY scheme as mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The key stakeholders involved in the implementation of the RSBY scheme include the district administration, the insurance companies, the hospitals, and the beneficiaries.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the role of the insurance companies in the RSBY scheme as per the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The insurance companies are responsible for providing the health insurance coverage to the beneficiaries under the RSBY scheme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How are the hospitals involved in the implementation of the RSBY scheme according to the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The hospitals are required to provide cashless and paperless treatment to the beneficiaries of the RSBY scheme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the responsibilities of the beneficiaries in the RSBY scheme as mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The beneficiaries are responsible for obtaining the smart card and using it to avail the health insurance benefits under the RSBY scheme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the process of claim settlement under the RSBY scheme as per the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The claims for the treatment of the beneficiaries are settled directly between the hospitals and the insurance companies.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How is the monitoring and evaluation of the RSBY scheme implementation carried out according to the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The monitoring and evaluation of the RSBY scheme implementation is done by the district administration and the state government.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the key challenges or issues mentioned in the document regarding the implementation of the RSBY scheme?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document mentions challenges such as ensuring the active participation of all stakeholders, effective monitoring and supervision, and creating awareness among the beneficiaries.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the role of the state government in the implementation of the RSBY scheme as per the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The state government is responsible for providing the necessary support and coordination for the effective implementation of the RSBY scheme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How does the document emphasize the importance of the RSBY scheme for the poor and underprivileged sections of society?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document highlights that the RSBY scheme is a crucial initiative to provide health insurance coverage to the poor and underprivileged, who often lack access to quality healthcare.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the specific instructions or guidelines provided in the document for the district administration regarding the implementation of the RSBY scheme?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document provides detailed instructions and guidelines for the district administration on various aspects of the scheme's implementation, such as enrollment, claim settlement, and monitoring.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How does the document stress the need for effective coordination and collaboration among the different stakeholders involved in the RSBY scheme?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document emphasizes the importance of coordination and collaboration among the district administration, insurance companies, hospitals, and beneficiaries for the successful implementation of the RSBY scheme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the timeline or schedule mentioned in the document for the various activities related to the RSBY scheme implementation?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document does not provide any specific timeline or schedule for the implementation activities, but it highlights the need for timely and efficient execution of the scheme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How does the document address the issue of creating awareness among the beneficiaries about the RSBY scheme?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document stresses the need for extensive awareness campaigns and outreach efforts to ensure that the beneficiaries are well-informed about the scheme and its benefits.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the specific responsibilities assigned to the district administration in the document for the effective implementation of the RSBY scheme?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The document outlines the district administration's key responsibilities, such as enrollment of beneficiaries, monitoring of hospitals, and coordination with insurance companies.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How does the document emphasize the importance of regular monitoring and evaluation of the RSBY scheme implementation?

question_answer_pairs.answer: The Implementing Agency with the approval of the Central Government shall issue procedures for implementation of these Rules.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: To whom shall the Uniform Renewable Energy Tariff under these Rules be applicable?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Uniform Renewable Energy Tariff under these Rules shall be applicable only to the Renewable energy generators for their contracted capacity which forms part of Central Pool under these Rules.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: In the Electricity Rules, 2005, for Rule 10, the following shall be substituted, namely.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What shall the Appropriate Commission do for resolution of dispute under Sections 79(f) and 86(f)?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Appropriate Commission shall pass a final order for resolution of dispute under Sections 79(f) and 86(f), within One Hundred and Twenty days from the date of receipt of the petition in the Commission, which may be extended by thirty days for reasons to be recorded in writing.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What shall happen if a final order cannot be issued by the Appropriate Commission?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Provided that if a final order cannot be issued, due to any reason, to be recorded in writing, then an interim order shall be issued by the Appropriate Commission, within the time line prescribed in Rule (1).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What may the affected party do if the final order has not been passed by the Appropriate Commission within the specified time?
question_answer_pairs.answer: If the final order has not been passed by the appropriate Commission, within Ninety days or One Hundred Eighty days, as the case may be, the affected party may approach the Appellate Tribunal for Electricity for appropriate relief.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: When were the Principal Rules published in the Gazette of India?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Principal Rules were published 2005 in the Gazette of India vide notification number G.S.R 379 (E), dated the 8th June, 2005.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: When were the subsequent amendments to the Principal Rules published in the Gazette of India?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The subsequent amendments to the Principal Rules were published vide notification number G.S.R 667 (E), dated the 28th October, 2006 and notification number G.S.R. 817 (E) dated 31st December, 2020.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the title of the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: PRESS RELEASE\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the date of the press release?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Patna, 22 June 2014\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who is the Hon'ble Minister for Health & Family Welfare mentioned in the document?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Dr Harsh Vardhan\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What was the purpose of Dr Harsh Vardhan's visit to Bihar?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The visit was aimed at appreciation of the situation on the ground in one of the disease affected States where morbidity and mortality of children in the current outbreak of encephalitis related disease had attracted focused concern of the Ministry.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Which district did Dr Harsh Vardhan visit in Muzaffarpur?
question_answer_pairs.answer: In Muzaffarpur District, Dr Harsh Vardhan went to some of the affected villages.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Where did Dr Harsh Vardhan go in Muzaffarpur District?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Dr Harsh Vardhan went to Intensive Care Units in Sri Krishna Government Medical College Hospital and to AES Ward of Shri Krishna Medical College Hospital.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What was Dr Harsh Vardhan informed about regarding the progress of the health sector?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Dr Harsh Vardhan was informed about the progress of the health sector and the proposed 'Swasthya Chetna' health sector reforms by the Bihar Health Secretary in a meeting at District Headquarters that continued till late night.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who attended the meeting with Dr Harsh Vardhan?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The meeting was attended by Bihar Health Minister, Members of Parliament and MLAs of Bihar belonging to BJP, Professors of Medical College, other medical professionals, WHO experts, UNICEF experts, American experts from CDC and teams of District Officials.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Dr Harsh Vardhan announce after the meeting?
question_answer_pairs.answer: After the meeting, Dr Harsh Vardhan urged the State Government to go beyond the targets set for the 2nd generation health sector reforms, specifically in respect of IMR, MMR and immunization coverage. He announced a series of packages by the Central Government.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did the Union Health Minister announce regarding diseases such as Kala Azar, Measles, Filariasis etc
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Union Health Minister announced that diseases such as Kala Azar, Measles, Filariasis etc. would be eradicated from the country in the coming years, and that 100 per cent vaccination should be ensured so that no child is left out of immunization.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What would be set up at SK Medical College Hospital?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A 100-bed Paediatric ICU would be set up at SK Medical College Hospital.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What would be set up in the adjoining districts?
question_answer_pairs.answer: In the adjoining districts, 10-bed Paediatric ICUs would be set up.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What would be upgraded at SK Medical College Hospital?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The SK Medical College Hospital would be upgraded to super-specialty standards.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How many Virological Diagnostic Laboratories will be set up in the State?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Five Virological Diagnostic Laboratories will be set up in the State at Gaya, Bhagalpur, Betiah, Purnea and Muzaffarpur.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What new research initiatives on encephalitis were announced?
question_answer_pairs.answer: New research initiatives on encephalitis were announced.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What would be set up in Muzaffarpur district?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A Model Rural Health Research Unit on Kala Azar would be set up in Muzaffarpur district.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did the officials request to look into extension of medical seats from 150 to 250?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The officials requested to look into extension of medical seats from 150 to 250.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did the officials request to meet MCI requirements for medical seat extension?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The officials requested to meet MCI requirements for medical seat extension.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Dr Harsh Vardhan state would be the need of all actions?
question_answer_pairs.answer: He stressed the need of preventive health and making healthy Indians a mass movement by enlisting participation of all sections.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Kala Azar, Measles, and Filariasis.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: 100 per cent vaccination should be ensured.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: 10-bed Paediatric ICUs would be set up in the adjoining districts.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Gaya, Bhagalpur, Betiah, Purnea and Muzaffarpur.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: A Model Rural Health Research Unit on Kala Azar would be set up in Muzaffarpur district.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The officials requested to look into extension of medical seats from 150 to 250.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The officials requested to meet MCI requirements for medical seat extension.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Preventive health and making healthy Indians a mass movement by enlisting participation of all sections.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the workshop mentioned in the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The workshop is on \"Tips for X-class low achievers to get pass marks in Biological Science\".\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the first tip mentioned for building confidence among low achievers?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Buildup confidence among the law achievers and motivate the students towards the studies.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the second tip mentioned for teachers to help low achievers?
question_answer_pairs.answer: We (Teachers) have to advise the students attempt all the questions in the public examinations with related answers to get at least pass marks.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the important key concepts that should be explained to low achievers according to the third tip?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Some important key concepts should be explained to the low achievers and allow them to write repeatedly to avoid spelling mistakes.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the 9 different topics mentioned that teachers may give important differences with simple sentences?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The 9 topics are: 1) Dark and light reactions, 2) Respiration & combustion, 3) Photosynthesis and respiration, 4) Arteries & Veins, 5) Excretion and Secretion, 6) Mitosis and Meiosis, 7) Central nervous system and peripheral nervous system, 8) Homologous and Analogous organs, and 9) Types of Tropisims.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The image mentions that teachers should provide at least four slogans regarding 1) Conservation of water, 2) Organ donation, 3) Environment, and 4) Conservation of forests.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The ninth key concept mentioned is Types of Tropisims.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the first slogan topic mentioned that should be provided?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The first slogan topic mentioned is Conservation of water.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the second slogan topic mentioned that should be provided?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The second slogan topic mentioned is Organ donation.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the third slogan topic mentioned that should be provided?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The third slogan topic mentioned is Environment.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the fourth slogan topic mentioned that should be provided?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The fourth slogan topic mentioned is Conservation of forests.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the first tip mentioned for building confidence among law achievers?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The first tip is to build up confidence among the law achievers and motivate the students towards the studies.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the second tip mentioned for teachers to help students get at least pass marks?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The second tip is for teachers to advise the students to attempt all the questions in the public examinations with related answers to get at least pass marks.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the third tip mentioned for explaining key concepts to low achievers?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The third tip is to explain some important key concepts to the low achievers and allow them to write repeatedly to avoid spelling mistakes.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the 9 different topics mentioned that teachers may explain with simple sentences?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The 9 topics are listed in the image.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the fifth tip mentioned for providing slogans regarding certain topics?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The fifth tip is to provide at least four slogans on the mentioned topics.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the sixth tip mentioned for preparing simple questions?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The sixth tip is to prepare simple questions for the following organs.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the association mentioned in the image organizing the workshop?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The workshop is organized by APREI Society & MJPAP BCWREI Society in association with APREI.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the workshop mentioned in the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The workshop is on \"Tips for X-class low achievers to get pass marks in Biological Science\".\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should teachers do to help students attempt all the questions in the public examinations?
question_answer_pairs.answer: We (Teachers) have to advise the students attempt all the questions in the public examinations with related answers to get at least pass marks.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should teachers do to help low achievers avoid spelling mistakes?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Some important key concepts should be explained to the low achievers and allow them to write repeatedly to avoid spelling mistakes.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different topics that teachers may explain with simple sentences?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Teachers may give them important differences with simple sentences on 1) Dark and light reactions, 2) Respiration & combustion, 3) Photosynthesis and respiration, 4) Arteries & Veins, 5) Excretion and Secretion, 6) Mitosis and Meiosis, 7) Central nervous system and peripheral nervous system, 8) Homologous and Analogous organs, and 9) Types of Tropisms.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the four slogans regarding conservation and environment that should be provided?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The four slogans are 1) Conservation of water, 2) Organ donation, 3) Environment, and 4) Conservation of forests.

question_answer_pairs.question: What does the procedure for Petty Repairs cover?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The procedure for Petty Repairs covers petty repair cases since the definition of Procurement, as given in Para 3.1, Part-B, DFPDS-2015, covers repair cases also.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the simplified procedure given for making emergency repairs of equipments/vehicles?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A simplified procedure for making emergency repairs of equipments/vehicles is given below. Any emergency repair of equipments/vehicles being made upto Rs 15,000/- will be covered under this procedure.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How can cases of breakdown or emergency repairs of equipments/vehicles be intimated?
question_answer_pairs.answer: All such cases of breakdown or emergency repairs of equipments/vehicles can be orally intimated to the CFA, who can permit carrying out emergency repair of equipments/vehicles upto Rs 15,000/- through a provisional oral approval to a Designated Authority.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How can the repair activities and payment thereof be initiated based on the provisional oral approval?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The repair activities and payment thereof through Imprest (if authorized to the unit/formation) can be initiated based on this provisional oral approval.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How will the case be processed in writing for getting it regularized through formal sanction of IFA?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Subsequently, the case will be processed in writing for getting it regularized through formal sanction of IFA (where dispensation is not given under Para 12.2.4, Part-B, DFPDS-2015) / CFA at the earliest.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will be the procedure for Petty Procurement that will be followed for regularization of such emergency cases?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The procedure applicable for Petty procurement will be followed for regularization of such emergency cases.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What details will be given in the certificate for carrying out such repairs?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A certificate, giving details like emergency reasons for carrying out such repairs, mode of carrying out repairs, etc., will be given by the Designated Authority. The same will be placed along with the proforma for obtaining concurrence / approval by IFA (where dispensation is not given under Para 12.2.4, Part-B, DFPDS-2015) / CFA.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Will such sanctions be treated as ex-post facto?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Such sanctions will not be treated as ex-post facto.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: As per Para 3.1, Part-B, DFPDS-2015, the definition of Procurement covers repair cases also.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: However, a more liberal procedure for emergency repair of equipments/vehicles is being given due to unique peculiarities of such cases.\n

What are the guiding principles that the strategy will need to be based on?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The strategy will need to be based on some guiding principles, which may include ownership, partnership, inter-linkages, and target-oriented strategy.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Why is ownership important for the State's export strategy?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Ownership is important for the State's export strategy to be firmly rooted and representative of the State's interests.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the pilot phase clearly state regarding the development of an export strategy?
question_answer_pairs.answer: If there is limited or no interest in the State, then the formulation and subsequent implementation of the State's export strategy would be compromised.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How would a partnership and an inclusive approach enrich the export strategy?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A partnership and an inclusive approach would enrich the export strategy by involving all interested state stakeholders, including the relevant line ministries, departments and bodies.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who should the export strategy involve?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The export strategy should involve all interested state stakeholders, including the relevant line ministries, departments and bodies; the private sector (representatives of agriculture cooperatives, industry/producer associations and service sector representatives); and other interested parties (e.g., academia, media etc.).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What could guide and manage the export strategy?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Stakeholder consultations and/or other mechanisms/arrangements could guide and manage the export strategy.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How should the export strategy be viewed?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Inter-linkages are needed so that the export strategy is not viewed in isolation. Rather, the strategy should be intertwined with other development objectives in the State.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should exports be geared to?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Exports should be geared to generate growth, employment and income in the State.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What could be explored in terms of backward and forward linkages?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Backward and forward linkages should be explored. Bottlenecks, where identified, could also be addressed.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the target-oriented strategy with follow-up be based on?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The target-oriented strategy with follow-up should be based on the needs identified to boost exports at the State level.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the export strategy formulation not be and what should it rather be?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The export strategy formulation should not be the end in itself but rather the means to analyze exportable goods and services in the State; opportunities and impediments to export; and provide the basis to develop policies/projects/programs to boost exports and ease trade bottlenecks in the State.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What may the formulation of an export strategy at the State level draw on?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Formulating an export strategy at the State level may draw on existing methodologies, such as the support provided by the International Trade Centre (ITC) for several years.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the Enhanced Integrated Framework (EIF) and Aid for Trade (AfT) initiatives useful for?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Enhanced Integrated Framework (EIF) and Aid for Trade (AfT) initiatives are useful points of reference.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the principal output of the export strategy document for the State be?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The principal output is a coherent, comprehensive and prioritized export strategy document for the State.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should the export strategy provide a blueprint for?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The export strategy should provide a blueprint for competitiveness and development of the State's export sector.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How could the export strategy be developed?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The export strategy could be developed from a diagnostic study and complemented with an action matrix highlighting needs and implementation priorities to boost exports in the State.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What would the diagnostic study assess?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The diagnostic study should assess the competitiveness of the State's economy and of the sectors that are engaged or have the potential to engage in exports/international trade.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What would the diagnosis help identify?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The diagnosis would help identify constraints to competitiveness, supply chain weaknesses and sectors of greatest growth and/or export potential.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the relationship between the ITC and Rs 3 lakh, as stated in the first line?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The ITC is equal to Rs 3 lakh.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What type of fabrics does the manufacturer produce, according to the passage?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The manufacturer produces grey manmade fibre fabrics and cotton fabrics.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: For what period does the passage discuss the refund of fabrics?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The passage discusses the refund of fabrics from July 2017 to July 2018.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the amount of ITC that was blocked subsequently by inverting entries in notification No
question_answer_pairs.answer: The amount of ITC that was blocked is Rs 25 lakh.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the amount of ITC that the AAMT fabric has inverted duty structure while the fabric does not have inverted duty structure?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The amount of ITC is Rs 10 lakh.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the formula used to calculate the accumulated ITC on account of inverted duty structure?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The formula is (Turnover of inverted rated supply of goods - Adjusted Total Turnover) x Net ITC/Adjusted Total Turnover.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the amount of ITC that shall be equal to nil, as per the passage?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The accumulated ITC on account of inverted duty structure shall be equal to nil (5/7*35-25).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How does the manner of calculation provided in rule 89(5) apply, according to the passage?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The manner of calculation provided in rule 89(5) would mutatis mutandis apply.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What does the application of the formula prescribed in rule 89(5) ensure, as illustrated in the passage?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The application of the formula ensures that ITC relating to capital goods and input services does not lapse.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What concern has been expressed regarding the proposed amendment, according to the passage?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The concern is that the proposed amendment seeks to lapse only such credit that has been accumulated on account of inverted duty structure.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is clarified regarding the proposed amendment, as per the passage?
question_answer_pairs.answer: It is clarified that the proposed amendment seeks to lapse only such credit that has been accumulated on inputs on account of inverted duty structure.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What may be excluded for the determination of Net ITC for the purposes of applying the said formula, according to the passage?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The input tax credit involved in inputs contained in such stock (including inputs lying as such) may be excluded for the determination of Net ITC.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: For what purpose may the ITC relating to inputs contained in stock may be determined in the manner as provided in S
question_answer_pairs.answer: The ITC relating to inputs contained in stock may be determined in the manner as provided in S. No. 7 of Form GST ITC-01 for the purpose of applying the said formula.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the turnover of inverted rated supply of goods, as mentioned in the formula?

question_answer_pairs.question: What services are being provided by the port authorities to its clients in relation to cargo handling?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The various services being provided by the port authorities to its clients in relation to cargo handling include arrival of wagons at port, handling of wagons inside the port, unloading of wagons, movement of unloaded cargo to plot and staking thereof, movement of unloaded cargo to berth, shipment/loading on vessel etc.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Doubts have been raised about the determination of place of supply for services i.e. whether the same would be determined in terms of the provisions contained in sub-section (2) of Section 12 or sub-section (2) of Section 13 of the IGST Act, as the case may be.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the clarification provided regarding the place of supply in case of performance-based services on unpolished diamonds?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The place of supply in case of performance-based services on unpolished diamonds such as cutting and polishing activity which have been temporarily imported into India and are not put to any use in India is to be determined as per the provisions contained in clause (a) of sub-section (3) of Section 13 of the IGST Act and generally the place of services is where the services are actually performed.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: An exception has been carved out in case of services supplied in respect of goods which are temporarily imported into India for repairs or for any other treatment or processing.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The services provided by the port authorities to its clients in relation to cargo handling are ancillary to, or related to cargo handling services and are not related to immovable property.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The place of supply of such services will be determined as per the provisions contained in sub-section (2) of Section 12 or sub-section (2) of Section 13 of the IGST Act, as the case may be, depending upon the terms of the contract between the supplier and recipient of such services.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the basis for determining the place of supply for the cargo handling services provided by the port authorities?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The place of supply of such services will be determined as per the provisions contained in sub-section (2) of Section 12 or sub-section (2) of Section 13 of the IGST Act, as the case may be, depending upon the terms of the contract between the supplier and recipient of such services.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the specific cargo handling services provided by the port authorities to its clients?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The specific services include arrival of wagons at port, handling of wagons inside the port, unloading of wagons, movement of unloaded cargo to plot and staking thereof, movement of unloaded cargo to berth, shipment/loading on vessel etc.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What services are being provided by the port authorities to its clients in relation to cargo handling?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The various services being provided by the port authorities to its clients in relation to cargo handling include arrival of wagons at port, handling of wagons inside the port, unloading of wagons, movement of unloaded cargo to plot and staking thereof, movement of unloaded cargo to berth, shipment/loading on vessel etc.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What doubts have been raised about the determination of place of supply for such services?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Doubts have been raised about the determination of place of supply for such services i.e. whether the same would be determined in terms of the provisions contained in sub-section (2) of Section 12 or sub-section (2) of Section 13 of the IGST Act, as the case may be.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the clarification provided regarding the place of supply in case of performance-based services on unpolished diamonds?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The place of supply in case of performance-based services on unpolished diamonds such as cutting and polishing activity which have been temporarily imported into India and are not put to any use in India is to be determined as per the provisions contained in clause (a) of sub-section (3) of Section 13 of the IGST Act and generally the place of services is where the services are actually performed.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the exception mentioned regarding the place of supply for services supplied in respect of goods which are temporarily imported into India?
question_answer_pairs.answer: An exception has been carved out in case of services supplied in respect of goods which are temporarily imported into India for repairs or for any other treatment or processing.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the issue raised regarding the place of supply for various services provided by the port authorities?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Doubts have been raised about the determination of place of supply for the various services provided by the port authorities in relation to cargo handling.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the various cargo handling services provided by the port authorities as per the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The various cargo handling services provided by the port authorities include arrival of wagons at port, handling of wagons inside the port, unloading of wagons, movement of unloaded cargo to plot and staking thereof, movement of unloaded cargo to berth, shipment/loading on vessel etc.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How is the place of supply for performance-based services on unpolished diamonds determined?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The place of supply for performance-based services on unpolished diamonds such as cutting and polishing activity which have been temporarily imported into India and are not put to any use in India is to be determined as per the provisions contained in clause (a) of sub-section (3) of Section 13 of the IGST Act.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the general principle for determining the place of services as per the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Generally, the place of services is where the services are actually performed.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the exception provided regarding the place of supply for services supplied in respect of goods temporarily imported into India?
question_answer_pairs.answer: An exception has been carved out in case of services supplied in respect of goods which are temporarily imported into India for repairs or for any other treatment or processing.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the clarification provided regarding the services provided by the port authorities being ancillary to or related to cargo handling?
question_answer_pairs.answer: It is hereby clarified that such services provided by the port authorities to its clients in relation to cargo handling are ancillary to, or related to cargo handling services and are not related to immovable property.\n\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How is the place of supply for the various services provided by the port authorities to be determined as per the circular?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The place of supply for the various services provided by the port authorities is to be determined in terms of the provisions contained in sub-section (2) of Section 12 or sub-section (2) of Section 13 of the IGST Act, as the case may be, depending upon the terms of the contract between the supplier and recipient of such services.

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the right of the Central Government or the State Government if they have guaranteed the repayment of principal and payment of interest on debentures issued by a multi-state cooperative society?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Government or the State Government shall have the right to nominate persons on the board of such a society in the manner as may be prescribed.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the right of the Central Government or the State Government if they have guaranteed the repayment of principal and payment of interest on loans and advances to a multi-state cooperative society?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Government or the State Government shall have the right to nominate persons on the board of such a society in the manner as may be prescribed.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the right of the Central Government or the State Government if they have given any assistance by way of grants or otherwise to a multi-state cooperative society?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Government or the State Government shall have the right to nominate persons on the board of such a society in the manner as may be prescribed.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who shall have the right to nominate persons on the board of a multi-state cooperative society if the Central Government or the State Government has guaranteed the repayment of principal and payment of interest on debentures issued by the society, or has guaranteed the repayment of principal and payment of interest on loans and advances to the society, or has given any assistance by way of grants or otherwise to the society?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Government or the State Government, as the case may be, or any person authorised by the Central Government, shall have the right to nominate persons on the board of such a society in the manner as may be prescribed.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the duration of office for a person nominated under this section?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A person nominated under this section shall hold office during the pleasure of the Government by which he has been so nominated.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What shall the money recovered through FPPAS first be accounted towards?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The oldest carry forward portion of the FPPAS followed by the subsequent month(s).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the carrying cost allowed for the carry forward of FPPAS?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Marginal cost of Funds-based lending Rate (SBIMLR) plus one hundred and fifty basis points.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The automatic pass through shall be adjusted such that.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: 95% cost recoverable.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: If 5%< FPPAS ≤10%, what percentage of FPPAS recoverable by distribution licensees shall be levied onto the consumers?
question_answer_pairs.answer: 6% FPPAS recoverable by distribution licensees shall be levied onto the consumers.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: If FPPAS >10%, what percentage of FPPAS recoverable by distribution licensees may be levied onto the consumers?
question_answer_pairs.answer: 10% FPPAS recoverable by distribution licensees may be levied onto the consumers.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: 1.20 times of the carrying cost rate approved by the State Commission.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The Ministry reserves the right to cancel the recruitment without assigning any reason.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the minimum and maximum possession of the same that does not entitle candidates to be called for interview?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The possession of the same does not entitle candidates to be called for interview if the number of applications received is large.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What will the Ministry do if the number of candidates to be called for interview is large?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Ministry reserves the right to restrict the number of candidates to be called for interview to a reasonable limit on the basis of desirable qualifications and/or experience.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Experience will be counted after completion of essential academic qualifications.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What shall be communicated to the multi-state cooperative society within a period of three months from the date of completion of the inspection?
question_answer_pairs.answer: A copy of the report of inspection under this section shall be communicated to the multi-state cooperative society within a period of three months from the date of completion of such inspection.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who shall inspect the books of indebted multi-state cooperative societies?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Registrar shall, on the application of a creditor of a multi-state cooperative society, inspect, or direct some person authorised by him by order in writing in this behalf to inspect, the books of the society.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the two conditions that must be satisfied before the Central Registrar can inspect the books of a multi-state cooperative society?
question_answer_pairs.answer: (a) The applicant satisfies the Central Registrar that the debt is a sum then due, and that he has demanded payment thereof and has not received satisfaction within a reasonable time; (b) The applicant deposits with the Central Registrar such sum as security for the costs of the proposed inspection as the Central Registrar may require.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What shall the Central Registrar communicate to the creditor after the inspection?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Registrar shall communicate the result of any such inspection to the creditor.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who may apportion the costs of an inquiry or inspection held under section 78 or section 79?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Registrar may apportion the costs, or such part of the costs, as he may think fit, between the multi-state cooperative society, the members or creditors demanding an inquiry or inspection, and the officers or former officers and the members or past members of that society.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Under what condition shall no order of apportionment of the costs be made under this section?
question_answer_pairs.answer: No order of apportionment of the costs shall be made under this section unless the society or the person liable to pay the costs thereunder has had a reasonable opportunity of being heard.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who shall state in writing under his own hand the grounds on which the costs are apportioned?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Registrar shall state in writing under his own hand the grounds on which the costs are apportioned.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What may be recovered by way of costs under section 81?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Any sum awarded by way of costs under section 81 may be recovered on application to a magistrate having jurisdiction in the place where the person, from whom the money is claimable, actually and voluntarily resides or carries on business, and such magistrate shall recover the same as if it were a fine imposed by himself.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose of the inspection is to inspect the books of the society on the application of a creditor of the multi-state cooperative society.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: Who may the Central Registrar authorize to inspect the books of a multi-state cooperative society?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The Central Registrar may direct some person authorised by him by order in writing to inspect the books of the society.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the two themes in social studies lessons covered in the content instructions?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The two themes are lessons from 1 to 12 cover paper - I and lessons from 13 to 22 cover paper - II under the second theme.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should pupils focus on according to the content instructions?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Pupils should focus on Tables, Pie - diagrams, Bar diagrams, time line Chart, Graphs for Good scoring.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should pupils do to better understand the matter?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Pupils should go through the text at a glance for better understanding the matter.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How many times should the given passage items be read to provide good comprehension over the questions?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Twice or thrice of reading of the given passage items will provide good comprehension over the questions.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should pupils practice for Paper - I and Paper - II?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Pupils should go on practice over Map reading and Map pointing. India Map will be given for Paper - I and World Map will be given for Paper - II. Students should practice various places from North to South and East to West.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is expected from the pupils in Part - B?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Ample practice is needed to score well in Part - B. And you are expected to revise previous question papers and guess papers as many times as possible.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What should pupils not waste their time on in the examination?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Don't waste your valuable time in the examination on any particular items as all are important in scoring well in the examination.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: In the \"My e-filed cases\" section, you can see your list of filed cases, e-filed documents, deficit court fee paid, the list of Interlocutory Applications, the list of Rejected Cases, and the list of Unprocessed e-Filed cases.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What is the purpose of the \"New Case Option\" under the dashboard?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The purpose of the \"New Case Option\" under the dashboard is to direct you to the form where you can file a new case.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How can you access the form to file a new case using the dashboard?
question_answer_pairs.answer: You can access the form to file a new case by clicking on the \"New Case Option\" under the dashboard.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What are the different types of cases shown in the \"e-filed cases\" section?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The different types of cases shown in the \"e-filed cases\" section are your list of filed cases, e-filed documents, deficit court fee paid, the list of Interlocutory Applications, the list of Rejected Cases, and the list of Unprocessed e-Filed cases.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What does the scheme entail according to the image?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The scheme entails demand based infrastructure creation by the State Discoms contingent to submission of action plans for improving operational and financial performance.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: How would the funds under the scheme be released?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The funds under the scheme would be released in proportion to the achievement by the Discoms against the mutually agreed targets in the action plan.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Delhi and Odisha suggest regarding the scheme?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Delhi and Odisha suggested that the scheme should be extended to private Discoms as well.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: When did Odisha suggest the existing schemes should be extended till?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Odisha suggested that the existing schemes should be extended till 31st March, 2021.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Punjab state regarding some of the old PPAs with NTPC?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Punjab stated that some of the old PPAs with NTPC had expired in the year 1997.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Punjab request regarding capacity charges for power plants covered under the PPA?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Punjab should not be forced to pay capacity charges for such power plants and requested that ISTS charges be reduced further by at least 50% during COVID period.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What appeal did Bihar make regarding \"One Nation One Tariff\"?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Bihar made an appeal for \"One Nation One Tariff\" in line with \"One Nation One Grid\", \"One Nation One Frequency\" and \"One Nation One Ration Card\".\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What issue did Bihar also highlight?
question_answer_pairs.answer: The issue of non-availability of pre-paid meters was also highlighted by Bihar.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did J&K request to set up?
question_answer_pairs.answer: J&K requested to set up a thermal power plant to meet the base load requirement of J&K.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Odisha request regarding large hydro power projects?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Odisha requested to make all large hydro power projects, irrespective of their date of commissioning, to be eligible for meeting the requirements of Hydro Power Obligation (HPO).\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Odisha suggest regarding the Tariff Policy?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Odisha suggested that the Tariff Policy should be a guiding policy and not a binding policy.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Kerala suggest regarding large hydro power projects?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Kerala suggested to make eligible all large hydro power projects for meeting HPO and requested to keep the interest of the farmers in mind in all policies.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Kerala request regarding further reduction in capacity charges?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Kerala requested for further reduction in capacity charges.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What did Haryana highlight regarding AT&C losses and the performance of its Discoms?
question_answer_pairs.answer: Haryana highlighted the substantial reduction of AT&C losses and the improved performance of its Discoms, which was commended and appreciated.\n

question_answer_pairs.question: What was requested to be taken care of in view of the contribution of the farmers to the economy, especially during COVID times?
question_answer_pairs.answer: It was requested to take care of the interest of farmers while framing new policy/law.\n

question_answer_pairs.answer: Haryana requested for Rs 1600 crore funding under PSDP.\n
